post.author: efx
post.body:
mfh1900 wrote:
it is not a horizontal level, because i have some stairs. even if u dont like my map - it is my first map i made. So how was looking your first map u made?


If you're going to post your work here you're going to have to expect to take critiscm. I don't know if it's a language thing here but you're coming across as a bit defensive.

Might as well give some comments too. What I like is that you're aligning the textures well and that's fairly uncommon for people starting out. The architecture, while somewhat flat as someone stated and maybe a bit boxy looks believable enough to be a real structure.

My negative points are that if you need a flashlight to show off your map it's too dark. In general the map could do with a bit more light in it. Also, in the 4th screenshot from the top with the busted little pipe with the fire coming out I wouldn't seal the pipe with a patch like you did but rather create an inside pipe that's a little smaller than the outside one and line up a series of meshes as an outside "ring" of sorts.

Keep it up.

post.author: Infernal=WFR
post.body:
The left most image of that circular hallway. The 2 panel ceiling texture and the walls look very plain. As well, you have a light in that picture with no apparent light source.

Try to match all lighting with some brushwork/light models. These and other small things seem like tedium, but collectively, if they aren't done, it really throws off a person's perception of the map because it doesn't follow our built in expectations of seeing a light source when there is a lighting change. As well, seeing a single texture tiled to heck down a long wall. Most architects wouldn't have long plain walls and neither should d3/q4 level designers.
